Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge erred in concluding applicants did not meet residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicants provided incomplete documentation, had significant gaps in health card use, and extensive international travel
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship applications denied due to insufficient proof of residency
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of citizenship judge's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by citizenship judge in residency assessment
Assessment_Factor: Residency duration, documentation completeness, health card usage, travel history
Credibility_Assessment: Judge found documentation and evidence unconvincing
Evidence_Used: Residency records, health card data, travel logs
Application_Basis: Requirement of at least 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within 1,460 days prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Incomplete documentation, gaps in provincial health coverage, foreign travel
Governing_Rule: Applicants must prove 3 years of physical residence in Canada within 4 years before application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of continuous or sufficient presence in Canada
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; citizenship denial upheld
Cause_Description: Applicants failed to meet legal residency requirement for citizenship
Evidence_Handling: Documentation reviewed for consistency and reliability
Evidence_Issues: Inconsistent health card use, lack of corroborating residency evidence
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence deemed insufficient to establish required residency
Decision_Rationale: Judge's conclusion was reasonable based on available evidence
Evidentiary_Issues: Gaps in documentation and health coverage, extensive absences from Canada
